G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, a custody order may be modified by the Court upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and a determination that such modification is in the child's best interests.

Massachusetts Supplemental Probate and F.raw_text: Massachusetts Supplemental Probate and Family Court Rule 401
Massachusetts Supplemental Probate and F.proposition: Pursuant to Massachusetts Supplemental Probate and Family Court Rule 401, the Plaintiff certifies that she has made reasonable attempts to resolve the issues herein with the Defendant through direct communication, but these efforts have been unsuccessful.

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Numerous appellate decisions affirm that the primary consideration in modifying custody arrangements is the best interests of the child.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in custody matters the core inquiry is what is best for the child and cites multiple appellate decisions for that principle. It explains that judges must weigh all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child and applies that standard in reviewing the custody modification at issue. This directly affirms that the primary consideration in modifying custody arrangements is the child's best interests.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is ‘best for the child’….’ Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (2003). ‘The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge … [whose] findings … ‘must stand unless they are plainly wrong.’’ Id. at 845, quoting Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191 (1998). However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’ Custody of Kali, supra, quoting Rosenberg v. Merida, supra.

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Numerous appellate decisions affirm that the primary consideration in modifying custody arrangements is the best interests of the child.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly reiterates that custody determinations turn on the best interests of the child and treats that standard as the governing, primary consideration when allocating and reviewing custody. The court traces the historical roots of the best-interests standard, states that custody awards will not be sustained unless all relevant best-interests factors are weighed, and analyzes the trial judge’s decision through that lens. This directly supports the proposition that appellate decisions affirm the best interests of the child as the primary consideration in modifying or adjusting custody arrangements.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002)… Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’)… ‘The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge… [whose] findings in a custody case must stand unless they are plainly wrong.’”}

*Pierce v. Pierce*, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that custody orders must be modified where circumstances have made the existing arrangement detrimental to the child.
*Pierce v. Pierce*, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with modification of alimony obligations, not custody orders or standards for modifying custody based on detriment to the child. While it recites the general standard that a party seeking modification of alimony or child support must show a material change in circumstances, it never addresses custody, the welfare of a child, or modification of custody orders. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about custody modifications being required when an arrangement becomes detrimental to the child.
*Pierce v. Pierce*, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment.” Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368 (1981). Here, Rudolph was successful in modifying the divorce judgment with respect to his alimony obligation, but he did not succeed in terminating that obligation.

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: A relocation by one parent that impacts the child's access to school or stability constitutes a material change in circumstances.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The case deals with whether a custodial parent may relocate children out of the jurisdiction (to Greece) under a “real advantage” standard and how that bears on the best interests of the child. It does not address modification of an existing custody or visitation order on the ground of a ‘material change in circumstances,’ nor does it focus on school access or stability as a trigger for such a change. The opinion is about the initial authorization to relocate, not about treating relocation’s impact on school or stability as a material change justifying modification.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

*Esther v. Esther*, 63 Mass. App. Ct. 12.proposition: The exhaustion and academic difficulties Sophie has suffered as a result of the current midweek schedule raise serious concerns about her well-being, making modification necessary pursuant to *Esther v. Esther*, 63 Mass. App. Ct. 122 (2005).
*Esther v. Esther*, 63 Mass. App. Ct. 12.support_reasoning: The case excerpt is not Esther v. Esther at all, but Adoption of Rhona, dealing with termination of parental rights and psychological harm from severing a child’s bond with preadoptive parents. It does not involve parenting time schedules, midweek transitions, school exhaustion, or academic difficulties as a basis for modifying a custody/parenting schedule. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority that a child’s exhaustion and academic problems from a midweek schedule make modification necessary.
*Esther v. Esther*, 63 Mass. App. Ct. 12.relevant_excerpt: “Second, serious psychological harm would flow from the severance of the bonds between Rhona and her preadoptive parents. Following the reopening of the case and renewed visitation, Rhona, as noted supra, evinced worrisome behavior: she began having trouble sleeping and had nightmares when she did sleep; she developed abdominal pain and headaches; she lost her appetite and began vomiting; and she became anxious. In school, she became emotionally upset and began crying and acting out in anger.”

*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (198.proposition: Courts in Massachusetts have consistently held that midweek overnights must not interfere with a child's educational routine or well-being.
*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss midweek overnight visitation at all, nor any rule that such overnights must not interfere with a child’s educational routine or well-being. Its custody analysis focuses on jurisdiction, best interests, the children’s ties to Massachusetts and Germany, sibling relationships, and parental fitness. There is no mention of midweek overnights, school-night visitation schedules, or any consistent Massachusetts rule on that subject, so this case cannot be cited as authority for the claimed proposition.
*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (198.relevant_excerpt: “A Probate Court judge must settle custody in a manner that advances the best interests of the children… It would be in the best interests of Rosemary and Tony to have a continuing relationship with both parents, a result which the judge found could be more easily achieved if the children resided with their mother in Massachusetts in view of Anthony’s greater ability and propensity to travel.”

*Sullivan v. Sullivan*, 38 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: The Defendant's relocation to Cape Cod is a significant factor affecting the logistics and feasibility of midweek parenting time.
*Sullivan v. Sullivan*, 38 Mass. App. Ct.case_name: Rehab Associates v. Blue Cross & Blue Shield of Massachusetts, Inc.
*Sullivan v. Sullivan*, 38 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a contractual and statutory dispute between a medical provider (RANE) and Blue Cross over reimbursement for MRI services. It does not involve family law, parenting time, relocation, or any custody/visitation logistics. Therefore, it cannot support a proposition about how a parent's relocation to Cape Cod affects midweek parenting time.
*Sullivan v. Sullivan*, 38 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt:
We summarize the pertinent facts found by the Superior Court judge as well as some uncontested facts set forth in the record.
RANE operates a freestanding magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) facility... Blue Cross is a nonprofit hospital service corporation regulated by the Rate Setting Commission and governed under G. L. c. 176A... [T]his case presents an exception to the general rule in G. L. c. 176A, § 5, that Blue Cross may refuse to enter into a contract with an institutional provider.

*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (198.proposition: In determining the best interests of the child, courts consider the developmental and educational needs of the child, as supported by *Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).
*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on procedural defects and on the standard of parental unfitness versus best interests, not on enumerating or applying specific "developmental and educational needs" factors. While it briefly references the child’s growth, development, education, intelligence, and counseling, it does so in critiquing the lower court’s reasoning and stressing the need for clear findings of endangerment, not as an affirmative statement that courts generally consider developmental and educational needs in best-interests determinations. The case is thus a weak and indirect authority for that specific proposition.
*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (198.relevant_excerpt: The Legislature has declared that the policy of this Commonwealth is "to direct its efforts, first, to the strengthening and encouragement of family life for the protection and care of children; to assist and encourage the use by any family of all available resources to this end; and to provide substitute care of children only when the family itself or the resources available to the family are unable to provide the necessary care and protection to insure the rights of any child to sound health and normal physical, mental, spiritual and moral development."

*Guardianship of Victoria*, 473 Mass. 64.proposition: The Court is empowered to ensure that the custody arrangement supports the minor child’s need for rest and routine.
*Guardianship of Victoria*, 473 Mass. 64.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns subject-matter jurisdiction under the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction Act for an unaccompanied refugee minor; it does not address how a court structures or polices a custody arrangement to support a child’s need for rest or routine. The discussion of ‘best interest of the child’ is limited to jurisdictional connections (significant connection, availability of evidence), not substantive custodial conditions such as rest, schedule, or routine. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about custody arrangements and a child’s need for rest and routine.
*Guardianship of Victoria*, 473 Mass. 64.relevant_excerpt: “If there is no home State, paragraph (2) grants jurisdiction to Massachusetts courts if it is in the child’s best interest for the Commonwealth to assume jurisdiction because (i) she ‘and at least one contestant… have a significant connection with the Commonwealth, and (ii) there is available in the Commonwealth substantial evidence concerning the child’s present or future care, protection, training, and personal relationships.’ … These factors are met given the facts of this case.”

*G.A.L. v. O.R.P.*, 73 Mass. App. Ct. 14.proposition: Failure to modify the custody order under these changed circumstances would disrupt Sophie’s stability and well-being, contrary to her best interests.
*G.A.L. v. O.R.P.*, 73 Mass. App. Ct. 14.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt is a complex attorney-fee and malpractice dispute arising out of environmental and bankruptcy litigation; it does not concern child custody, modification of custody orders, or a best-interests-of-the-child analysis. The claimed proposition about disrupting Sophie’s stability and well-being through failure to modify a custody order is unrelated to the issues actually decided in this case. Accordingly, this case cannot be used as authority for that custody-related proposition.
